docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 DEFENDANT TO PROCEEDINGS TO ENTER APPEARANCE [rr 6.9–6.11]

heading.title: DIVISION 3 DEFENDANT TO PROCEEDINGS TO ENTER APPEARANCE [rr 6.9–6.11]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 3 DEFENDANT TO PROCEEDINGS TO ENTER APPEARANCE [rr 6.9–6.11]

leg:heading.title: DEFENDANT TO PROCEEDINGS TO ENTER APPEARANCE [rr 6.9–6.11]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.9] r 6.9 How appearance entered (cf SCR Part 11, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: How appearance entered (cf SCR Part 11, rule 3)

p.text: A defendant may enter an appearance in proceedings by filing a notice of appearance.
A defendant who files a defence in proceedings is taken to have entered an appearance in the proceedings.
Appearance may be withdrawn: see rule 12.5 .
The approved form for an Appearance is Form 6 .
Legislation cited in [6.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.11, r 12.11(3)(b), r 12.11(4).
(CTH) Foreign Judgments Act 1991 s 7(5).

There is no provision in the UCPR for the entry of a conditional appearance. However r 12.11 does permit a defendant to apply, within the time limited for entering an appearance, to set aside service of originating process. By providing that the application “may be filed without entering an appearance” the rule necessarily contemplates that a defendant who wishes to challenge the jurisdiction will not ordinarily enter an appearance. The defendant’s notice of motion must, however, bear a note stating the applicant’s address for service: r 12.11(3)(b) . The making of an application for an order under the rule does not constitute submission to the jurisdiction of the court: r 12.11(4) . In addition there are some statutory provisions that expressly provide that the entry of an appearance is not to be regarded as a voluntary submission to the jurisdiction of the court: for example, Foreign Judgments Act 1991 (Cth) s 7(5) .
Legislation cited in [6.9.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.11.

From time to time either the rules or the practice of the courts have permitted the entry of submitting, conditional and unconditional appearances. A submitting appearance is specifically permitted by r 6.11 of the UCPR and, as the name suggests, indicates not only that the party intends to take no active part in the proceedings but also that it will submit to any order that the court sees fit to make.

Subject to any contrary statutory provision, the entry of an unconditional appearance waives any objection to the jurisdiction of the court: Tozier v Hawkins (1885) 15 QBD 650 ; Moore v Gamgee (1890) 25 QBD 244 ; Suckan v Weiner (1901) 17 TLR 494; Re Orr Ewing (1882) 22 Ch D 456 ; A Lund & Co (Bilden Textiles) Ltd v Wembley Wear Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Full Court, 18 June 1957, unreported), noted 2 Syd LR 580; Clutha Developments Pty Ltd v Marion Power Shovel Co Inc [1973] 2 NSWLR 173 ; Henry v Geoprosco International Ltd [1976] QB 726 . Such an appearance also waives reliance upon any irregularities in the manner of the commencement or service of the proceedings: Sheldon v Brown Bayley’s Steel Works Ltd [1953] 2 QB 393 ; Re Chittenden [1970] 3 All ER 562; [1970] 1 WLR 1618 .

level.toc-caption: [6.9.20] Appearance not genuine — name of the party appearing

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.9.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 11 r 4(2).

heading.title: Appearance not genuine — name of the party appearing

p.text: It has been held that is not improper for a defendant to use a pseudonym and an appearance in such a name will not necessarily be struck out. However, a plaintiff is ordinarily entitled to know the real identity of the opposing party. Under the SCR Pt 11 r 4(2) , it was held that, if an appearance has been entered under a pseudonym, the court could grant the plaintiff leave to continue the proceedings as if the appearance had not been entered: Allied Mills Ltd v Robinson (1981) 2 BPR 9353 (leave suspended upon the condition that evidence be filed disclosing the true identity of the defendant). Although there is no explicit equivalent provision in the UCPR, a similar power would fall within the direction making and case management powers of the court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.10] r 6.10 Time for appearance (cf SCR Part 7, rule 5, and Part 11, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Time for appearance (cf SCR Part 7, rule 5, and Part 11, rule 6)

p.text: For the purposes of these rules, the time limited for a defendant to enter an appearance (whether by filing a notice of appearance in accordance with this Division or by filing a defence in accordance with Division 4) is:
in the case of proceedings commenced by statement of claim:
28 days after service on the defendant of the statement of claim or such other time as the court directs for the filing of a defence, or
if the defendant makes an unsuccessful application to have the statement of claim set aside, 7 days after the refusal of the application, whichever is the later, or
in the case of proceedings commenced by summons:
on or before the return day stated in the summons, or
if the defendant makes an unsuccessful application to have the summons set aside, 7 days after the refusal of the application, whichever is the later.

A reference in subrule (1)(b) to a summons extends, in relation to the Land and Environment Court, to an application that, in accordance with the rules of that Court, commences proceedings in Class 1, 2 or 3 of that Court’s jurisdiction.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[2], effective 28 January 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.11] r 6.11 Defendant may submit to judgment by notice of appearance (cf SCR Part 11, rule 4 (3), (4) and (5))

leg:heading.title: Defendant may submit to judgment by notice of appearance (cf SCR Part 11, rule 4 (3), (4) and (5))

p.text: A defendant who intends to take no active part in proceedings may include in the defendant’s notice of appearance a statement to the effect that the defendant submits to the making of all orders sought and the giving or entry of judgment in respect of all claims made, to which may be added the words ", save as to costs".

Except by leave of the court, a defendant who has filed a notice of appearance containing a statement referred to in subrule (1) may not file a defence or affidavit or take any other step in the proceedings.
See rule 20.34 which allows the defendant in proceedings on a liquidated claim to file a statement acknowledging the whole of the amount of the claim.
Legislation cited in [6.11.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16(2)(b).

The rule permits a defendant to file a submitting appearance if they do not intend to contest the proceedings. The most common use of submitting appearances is where the proceedings relate to the jurisdiction of inferior courts or tribunals, and they are merely formal parties to the proceedings: see R v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal; Ex parte Hardiman (1980) 144 CLR 13 at 35; 29 ALR 289; 54 ALJR 314; BC8000073 and see further [SCA s 69.15] . However any party may file a submitting appearance if they do not intend to contest the orders sought in the proceedings.

Where a party files a submitting appearance they cannot contest the plaintiff’s claim, or take any other step in the proceedings. This includes foregoing entitlement to either prior notice of, or subsequent objection under UCPR r 36.16(2)(b) to, the final orders — at least in the absence of any material change of circumstances: Fitter v Public Trustee [2007] NSWSC 1487; BC200711471 at [20] . Correspondingly, a submitting party will not ordinarily be liable for costs incurred after filing their submitting appearance: Develtor Property Group Pty Ltd v Newcastle City Council [2001] NSWLEC 47; BC200101144 .

Accordingly, a plaintiff who is met with a submitting appearance by all the parties with an interest in the proceedings is generally entitled to judgment without formal proof of its claim: Trust Company of Australia Ltd v Perpetual Trustees (WA) Ltd (No 2) (1995) 36 NSWLR 654; BC9504720 ; Develtor Property Group Pty Ltd v Newcastle City Council [2001] NSWLEC 47; BC200101144 . However, the court still retains a discretion to refuse relief and to require formal proof, if it appears that the entry of judgment pursuant to the submitting appearance is inappropriate in the circumstances. (The circumstances in which a court may refuse to make orders to which the parties consent are discussed in [36.1A.5] .)

The principles covering leave to withdraw appearances are discussed in the note at [12.5.5]. There has been some debate whether the provisions in Pt 6 or Pt 12 provide the appropriate provisions for withdrawal of a submitting appearance: see Sahab Holdings Pty Ltd v Registrar-General (2009) 75 NSWLR 629; [2009] NSWSC 1143; BC200909783 at [78]–[84] (Registrar-General required to withdraw submitting appearance after taking an active part in the proceedings) compare Hilton v Gidley [2009] NSWSC 383; BC200904263 at [18]–[19] (discussion of r 12.5 but no leave to withdraw submitting appearance); Evergreen Tours Pty Ltd v McLaren [2010] NSWSC 1362; BC201009033 (leave granted to withdraw submitting appearance under r 12.5).

level.toc-caption: [6.11.10] Submission to orders “save as to costs”

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.11.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 42.1, UCPR r 6.11(1).

heading.title: Submission to orders “save as to costs”

p.text: UCPR r 6.11(1) expressly permits a defendant to file an appearance submitting to the orders sought in the claim “save as to costs”. This permissive exception to the form of a submitting appearance implies that costs orders may in fact be made against defendant who otherwise submits to the relief claimed in the proceedings. Despite that implication, ordinarily a defendant who submits, whether formally or informally, and takes no part in the determination of issues that are actively contested by other parties, should not be ordered to pay any costs subsequently incurred in the conduct of the proceedings: Develtor Property Group Pty Ltd v Newcastle City Council [2001] NSWLEC 47; BC200101144 ; Probiotec Ltd v The University of Melbourne (2008) 166 FCR 30; 244 ALR 96; [2008] FCAFC 5; BC200800400 . Consistent with that ordinary position the Rules do not provide specifically for the consequences of an appearance in relation to costs, by a defendant who had previously filed a submitting appearance. Nevertheless the court’s general costs discretion under UCPR r 42.1 may be exercised, even against a party that has formally entered a submitting appearance, depending on the true extent of that party’s actual responsibility for the costs incurred in the proceedings: Mahenthirarasa v State Rail Authority of NSW (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 201; BC200807693 (sole respondent with active interest — submitting appearance — statutory corporation — prior opposition to relief claimed — costs order).
There seem to be 2 main streams of decisions dealing with the cost consequences of submitting appearances:

Judicial review proceedings — where the inferior court or tribunal has entered a submitting appearance — costs usually not awarded against the court or tribunal: El Deeb v Magistrates Court of SA (1999) 72 SASR 596 at 598; [1999] SASC 113; BC9901081 . But more recently there has been a greater inclination to award costs to successful applicant: R (Davies) v Birmingham Deputy Coroner [2004] 1 WLR 2739; [2004] 3 All ER 543; [2004] EWCA Civ 207 at [47] :

(1) the established practice of the courts was to make no order for costs against an inferior court or tribunal which did not appear before it except when there was a flagrant instance of improper behaviour or when the inferior court or tribunal unreasonably declined or neglected to sign a consent order disposing of the proceedings;

(2) the established practice of the courts was to treat an inferior court or tribunal which resisted an application actively by way of argument in such a way that it made itself an active party to the litigation, as if it was such a party, so that in the normal course of things costs would follow the event;

(3) if, however, an inferior court or tribunal appeared in the proceedings in order to assist the court neutrally on questions of jurisdiction, procedure, specialist case law and such like, the established practice of the courts was to treat it as a neutral party, so that it would not make an order for costs in its favour or an order for costs against it whatever the outcome of the application;

(4) there are, however, a number of important considerations which might tend to make the courts exercise their discretion in a different way today in cases in category (3) above, so that a successful applicant, like Mr Touche, who has to finance his own litigation without external funding, may be fairly compensated out of a source of public funds and not be put to irrecoverable expense in asserting his rights after a coroner, or other inferior tribunal, has gone wrong in law, and [where] there is no other very obvious candidate available to pay his costs.

In Kumar v Mitchell (1991) 32 FCR 190; 26 ALD 421 the applicant was detained by order of a magistrate; proceedings were against the magistrate and prosecutor; the magistrate did not appear; the prosecutor appeared and defended the proceedings: “the fact that that organ of the government has not been a party to the error does not mean that that party should be relieved of the obligation to pay costs.”
Councils filing submitting appearances in development consent proceedings to protect against costs:

Sidney Harrison P/L v City of Tea Tree Gully (No 2) (2001) 112 LGERA 327 at 332; [2001] SASC 34; BC200100430 : “There are steps by which a planning authority is able to minimise costs of any proceedings seeking to set aside the development consent. It may indicate to a plaintiff that it recognises that there are defects in the manner in which it has handled an application and might even be able to assist a court in framing appropriate orders with, of course, proper notice to the person who has the benefit of the development consent”.

Develtor Property Group P/L v Newcastle City Council [2001] NSWLEC 47; BC200101144 : Bignold J held at [42] that “the effect of the Respondent’s submitting appearance in the present case, where that appearance has not been challenged or impugned, is that the submitting party is generally to be regarded as immune from any liability for costs incurred in the proceedings after the filing of the submitting appearance save as to costs (although conformably to principle and case law, the submitting party will be liable for costs incurred by the plaintiff up to the date of the filing of the submitting appearance)”.

De Haas v Williams (2004) 132 LGERA 195; [2004] NSWLEC 15; BC200400247 at [71] : Conduct of council resulted in development consents being invalid. Council and beneficiary of the consents were respondents. Council took no active part in proceedings, filed no evidence. Filed notice of submitting appearance but did not notify applicants until day before proceedings, Both respondents ordered to pay costs.

Cutcliffe v Lithgow City Council [2006] NSWLEC 463; BC200605827 at [37] : Council actively defended proceedings, then submitted late. Applicants costs incurred prior to council’s submitting appearance. Applicant given order for costs against council (subject to discount). Council to have order for proportion of those costs against developer.

Trenwith v Sutherland Shire Council (No 3) [2006] NSWLEC 490; BC200607282 — Council filed a submitting appearance – still found liable for share of costs (caused the invalidity of the development consent).
Other types of situations:
Highland v Labraga (No 3) [2006] NSWSC 871; BC200606785 — proceedings to remove executor of estate. Defendant filed submitting appearance but still took part in proceedings.
